runtime/src/thirdparty/nedmalloc/malloc.c.h

Go to the documentation of this file.
00001 /*
00002   This is a version (aka dlmalloc) of malloc/free/realloc written by
00003   Doug Lea and released to the public domain, as explained at
00004   http://creativecommons.org/licenses/publicdomain.  Send questions,
00005   comments, complaints, performance data, etc to dl@cs.oswego.edu
00006 
00007 * Version 2.8.4 Wed May 27 09:56:23 2009  Doug Lea  (dl at gee)
00008 
00009    Note: There may be an updated version of this malloc obtainable at
00010            ftp://gee.cs.oswego.edu/pub/misc/malloc.c
00011          Check before installing!
00012 
00013 * Quickstart
00014 
00015   This library is all in one file to simplify the most common usage:
00016   ftp it, compile it (-O3), and link it into another program. All of
00017   the compile-time options default to reasonable values for use on
00018   most platforms.  You might later want to step through various
00019   compile-time and dynamic tuning options.
00020 
00021   For convenience, an include file for code using this malloc is at:
00022      ftp://gee.cs.oswego.edu/pub/misc/malloc-2.8.4.h
00023   You don't really need this .h file unless you call functions not
00024   defined in your system include files.  The .h file contains only the
00025   excerpts from this file needed for using this malloc on ANSI C/C++
00026   systems, so long as you haven't changed compile-time options about
00027   naming and tuning parameters.  If you do, then you can create your
00028   own malloc.h that does include all settings by cutting at the point
00029   indicated below. Note that you may already by default be using a C
00030   library containing a malloc that is based on some version of this
00031   malloc (for example in linux). You might still want to use the one
00032   in this file to customize settings or to avoid overheads associated
00033   with library versions.
00034 
00035 * Vital statistics:
00036 
00037   Supported pointer/size_t representation:       4 or 8 bytes
00038        size_t MUST be an unsigned type of the same width as
00039        pointers. (If you are using an ancient system that declares
00040        size_t as a signed type, or need it to be a different width
00041        than pointers, you can use a previous release of this malloc
00042        (e.g. 2.7.2) supporting these.)
00043 
00044   Alignment:                                     8 bytes (default)
00045        This suffices for nearly all current machines and C compilers.
00046        However, you can define MALLOC_ALIGNMENT to be wider than this
00047        if necessary (up to 128bytes), at the expense of using more space.
00048 
00049   Minimum overhead per allocated chunk:   4 or  8 bytes (if 4byte sizes)
00050                                           8 or 16 bytes (if 8byte sizes)
00051        Each malloced chunk has a hidden word of overhead holding size
00052        and status information, and additional cross-check word
00053        if FOOTERS is defined.
00054 
00055   Minimum allocated size: 4-byte ptrs:  16 bytes    (including overhead)
00056                           8-byte ptrs:  32 bytes    (including overhead)
00057 
00058        Even a request for zero bytes (i.e., malloc(0)) returns a
00059        pointer to something of the minimum allocatable size.
00060        The maximum overhead wastage (i.e., number of extra bytes
00061        allocated than were requested in malloc) is less than or equal
00062        to the minimum size, except for requests >= mmap_threshold that
00063        are serviced via mmap(), where the worst case wastage is about
00064        32 bytes plus the remainder from a system page (the minimal
00065        mmap unit); typically 4096 or 8192 bytes.
00066 
00067   Security: static-safe; optionally more or less
00068        The "security" of malloc refers to the ability of malicious
00069        code to accentuate the effects of errors (for example, freeing
00070        space that is not currently malloc'ed or overwriting past the
00071        ends of chunks) in code that calls malloc.  This malloc
00072        guarantees not to modify any memory locations below the base of
00073        heap, i.e., static variables, even in the presence of usage
00074        errors.  The routines additionally detect most improper frees
00075        and reallocs.  All this holds as long as the static bookkeeping
00076        for malloc itself is not corrupted by some other means.  This
00077        is only one aspect of security -- these checks do not, and
00078        cannot, detect all possible programming errors.
00079 
00080        If FOOTERS is defined nonzero, then each allocated chunk
00081        carries an additional check word to verify that it was malloced
00082        from its space.  These check words are the same within each
00083        execution of a program using malloc, but differ across
00084        executions, so externally crafted fake chunks cannot be
00085        freed. This improves security by rejecting frees/reallocs that
00086        could corrupt heap memory, in addition to the checks preventing
00087        writes to statics that are always on.  This may further improve
00088        security at the expense of time and space overhead.  (Note that
00089        FOOTERS may also be worth using with MSPACES.)
00090 
00091        By default detected errors cause the program to abort (calling
00092        "abort()"). You can override this to instead proceed past
00093        errors by defining PROCEED_ON_ERROR.  In this case, a bad free
00094        has no effect, and a malloc that encounters a bad address
00095        caused by user overwrites will ignore the bad address by
00096        dropping pointers and indices to all known memory. This may
00097        be appropriate for programs that should continue if at all
00098        possible in the face of programming errors, although they may
00099        run out of memory because dropped memory is never reclaimed.
00100 
00101        If you don't like either of these options, you can define
00102        CORRUPTION_ERROR_ACTION and USAGE_ERROR_ACTION to do anything
00103        else. And if if you are sure that your program using malloc has
00104        no errors or vulnerabilities, you can define INSECURE to 1,
00105        which might (or might not) provide a small performance improvement.
00106 
00107   Thread-safety: NOT thread-safe unless USE_LOCKS defined
00108        When USE_LOCKS is defined, each public call to malloc, free,
00109        etc is surrounded with either a pthread mutex or a win32
00110        spinlock (depending on WIN32). This is not especially fast, and
00111        can be a major bottleneck.  It is designed only to provide
00112        minimal protection in concurrent environments, and to provide a
00113        basis for extensions.  If you are using malloc in a concurrent
00114        program, consider instead using nedmalloc
00115        (http://www.nedprod.com/programs/portable/nedmalloc/) or
00116        ptmalloc (See http://www.malloc.de), which are derived
00117        from versions of this malloc.
00118 
00119   System requirements: Any combination of MORECORE and/or MMAP/MUNMAP
00120        This malloc can use unix sbrk or any emulation (invoked using
00121        the CALL_MORECORE macro) and/or mmap/munmap or any emulation
00122        (invoked using CALL_MMAP/CALL_MUNMAP) to get and release system
00123        memory.  On most unix systems, it tends to work best if both
00124        MORECORE and MMAP are enabled.  On Win32, it uses emulations
00125        based on VirtualAlloc. It also uses common C library functions
00126        like memset.
00127 
00128   Compliance: I believe it is compliant with the Single Unix Specification
00129        (See http://www.unix.org). Also SVID/XPG, ANSI C, and probably
00130        others as well.
00131 
00132 * Overview of algorithms
00133 
00134   This is not the fastest, most space-conserving, most portable, or
00135   most tunable malloc ever written. However it is among the fastest
00136   while also being among the most space-conserving, portable and
00137   tunable.  Consistent balance across these factors results in a good
00138   general-purpose allocator for malloc-intensive programs.
00139 
00140   In most ways, this malloc is a best-fit allocator. Generally, it
00141   chooses the best-fitting existing chunk for a request, with ties
00142   broken in approximately least-recently-used order. (This strategy
00143   normally maintains low fragmentation.) However, for requests less
00144   than 256bytes, it deviates from best-fit when there is not an
00145   exactly fitting available chunk by preferring to use space adjacent
00146   to that used for the previous small request, as well as by breaking
00147   ties in approximately most-recently-used order. (These enhance
00148   locality of series of small allocations.)  And for very large requests
00149   (>= 256Kb by default), it relies on system memory mapping
00150   facilities, if supported.  (This helps avoid carrying around and
00151   possibly fragmenting memory used only for large chunks.)
00152 
00153   All operations (except malloc_stats and mallinfo) have execution
00154   times that are bounded by a constant factor of the number of bits in
00155   a size_t, not counting any clearing in calloc or copying in realloc,
00156   or actions surrounding MORECORE and MMAP that have times
00157   proportional to the number of non-contiguous regions returned by
00158   system allocation routines, which is often just 1. In real-time
00159   applications, you can optionally suppress segment traversals using
00160   NO_SEGMENT_TRAVERSAL, which assures bounded execution even when
00161   system allocators return non-contiguous spaces, at the typical
00162   expense of carrying around more memory and increased fragmentation.
00163 
00164   The implementation is not very modular and seriously overuses
00165   macros. Perhaps someday all C compilers will do as good a job
00166   inlining modular code as can now be done by brute-force expansion,
00167   but now, enough of them seem not to.
00168 
00169   Some compilers issue a lot of warnings about code that is
00170   dead/unreachable only on some platforms, and also about intentional
00171   uses of negation on unsigned types. All known cases of each can be
00172   ignored.
00173 
00174   For a longer but out of date high-level description, see
00175      http://gee.cs.oswego.edu/dl/html/malloc.html
00176 
00177 * MSPACES
00178   If MSPACES is defined, then in addition to malloc, free, etc.,
00179   this file also defines mspace_malloc, mspace_free, etc. These
00180   are versions of malloc routines that take an "mspace" argument
00181   obtained using create_mspace, to control all internal bookkeeping.
00182   If ONLY_MSPACES is defined, only these versions are compiled.
00183   So if you would like to use this allocator for only some allocations,
00184   and your system malloc for others, you can compile with
00185   ONLY_MSPACES and then do something like...
00186     static mspace mymspace = create_mspace(0,0); // for example
00187     #define mymalloc(bytes)  mspace_malloc(mymspace, bytes)
00188 
00189   (Note: If you only need one instance of an mspace, you can instead
00190   use "USE_DL_PREFIX" to relabel the global malloc.)
00191 
00192   You can similarly create thread-local allocators by storing
00193   mspaces as thread-locals. For example:
00194     static __thread mspace tlms = 0;
00195     void*  tlmalloc(size_t bytes) {
00196       if (tlms == 0) tlms = create_mspace(0, 0);
00197       return mspace_malloc(tlms, bytes);
00198     }
00199     void  tlfree(void* mem) { mspace_free(tlms, mem); }
00200 
00201   Unless FOOTERS is defined, each mspace is completely independent.
00202   You cannot allocate from one and free to another (although
00203   conformance is only weakly checked, so usage errors are not always
00204   caught). If FOOTERS is defined, then each chunk carries around a tag
00205   indicating its originating mspace, and frees are directed to their
00206   originating spaces.
00207 
00208  -------------------------  Compile-time options ---------------------------
00209 
00210 Be careful in setting #define values for numerical constants of type
00211 size_t. On some systems, literal values are not automatically extended
00212 to size_t precision unless they are explicitly casted. You can also
00213 use the symbolic values MAX_SIZE_T, SIZE_T_ONE, etc below.
00214 
00215 WIN32                    default: defined if _WIN32 defined
00216   Defining WIN32 sets up defaults for MS environment and compilers.
00217   Otherwise defaults are for unix. Beware that there seem to be some
00218   cases where this malloc might not be a pure drop-in replacement for
00219   Win32 malloc: Random-looking failures from Win32 GDI API's (eg;
00220   SetDIBits()) may be due to bugs in some video driver implementations
00221   when pixel buffers are malloc()ed, and the region spans more than
00222   one VirtualAlloc()ed region. Because dlmalloc uses a small (64Kb)
00223   default granularity, pixel buffers may straddle virtual allocation
00224   regions more often than when using the Microsoft allocator.  You can
00225   avoid this by using VirtualAlloc() and VirtualFree() for all pixel
00226   buffers rather than using malloc().  If this is not possible,
00227   recompile this malloc with a larger DEFAULT_GRANULARITY.
00228 
00229 MALLOC_ALIGNMENT         default: (size_t)8
00230   Controls the minimum alignment for malloc'ed chunks.  It must be a
00231   power of two and at least 8, even on machines for which smaller
00232   alignments would suffice. It may be defined as larger than this
00233   though. Note however that code and data structures are optimized for
00234   the case of 8-byte alignment.
00235 
00236 MSPACES                  default: 0 (false)
00237   If true, compile in support for independent allocation spaces.
00238   This is only supported if HAVE_MMAP is true.
00239 
00240 ONLY_MSPACES             default: 0 (false)
00241   If true, only compile in mspace versions, not regular versions.
00242 
00243 USE_LOCKS                default: 0 (false)
00244   Causes each call to each public routine to be surrounded with
00245   pthread or WIN32 mutex lock/unlock. (If set true, this can be
00246   overridden on a per-mspace basis for mspace versions.) If set to a
00247   non-zero value other than 1, locks are used, but their
00248   implementation is left out, so lock functions must be supplied manually,
00249   as described below.
00250 
00251 USE_SPIN_LOCKS           default: 1 iff USE_LOCKS and on x86 using gcc or MSC
00252   If true, uses custom spin locks for locking. This is currently
00253   supported only for x86 platforms using gcc or recent MS compilers.
00254   Otherwise, posix locks or win32 critical sections are used.
00255 
00256 FOOTERS                  default: 0
00257   If true, provide extra checking and dispatching by placing
00258   information in the footers of allocated chunks. This adds
00259   space and time overhead.
00260 
00261 INSECURE                 default: 0
00262   If true, omit checks for usage errors and heap space overwrites.
00263 
00264 USE_DL_PREFIX            default: NOT defined
00265   Causes compiler to prefix all public routines with the string 'dl'.
00266   This can be useful when you only want to use this malloc in one part
00267   of a program, using your regular system malloc elsewhere.
00268 
00269 ABORT                    default: defined as abort()
00270   Defines how to abort on failed checks.  On most systems, a failed
00271   check cannot die with an "assert" or even print an informative
00272   message, because the underlying print routines in turn call malloc,
00273   which will fail again.  Generally, the best policy is to simply call
00274   abort(). It's not very useful to do more than this because many
00275   errors due to overwriting will show up as address faults (null, odd
00276   addresses etc) rather than malloc-triggered checks, so will also
00277   abort.  Also, most compilers know that abort() does not return, so
00278   can better optimize code conditionally calling it.
00279 
00280 PROCEED_ON_ERROR           default: defined as 0 (false)
00281   Controls whether detected bad addresses cause them to bypassed
00282   rather than aborting. If set, detected bad arguments to free and
00283   realloc are ignored. And all bookkeeping information is zeroed out
00284   upon a detected overwrite of freed heap space, thus losing the
00285   ability to ever return it from malloc again, but enabling the
00286   application to proceed. If PROCEED_ON_ERROR is defined, the
00287   static variable malloc_corruption_error_count is compiled in
00288   and can be examined to see if errors have occurred. This option
00289   generates slower code than the default abort policy.
00290 
00291 DEBUG                    default: NOT defined
00292   The DEBUG setting is mainly intended for people trying to modify
00293   this code or diagnose problems when porting to new platforms.
00294   However, it may also be able to better isolate user errors than just
00295   using runtime checks.  The assertions in the check routines spell
00296   out in more detail the assumptions and invariants underlying the
00297   algorithms.  The checking is fairly extensive, and will slow down
00298   execution noticeably. Calling malloc_stats or mallinfo with DEBUG
00299   set will attempt to check every non-mmapped allocated and free chunk
00300   in the course of computing the summaries.
00301 
00302 ABORT_ON_ASSERT_FAILURE   default: defined as 1 (true)
00303   Debugging assertion failures can be nearly impossible if your
00304   version of the assert macro causes malloc to be called, which will
00305   lead to a cascade of further failures, blowing the runtime stack.
00306   ABORT_ON_ASSERT_FAILURE cause assertions failures to call abort(),
00307   which will usually make debugging easier.
00308 
00309 MALLOC_FAILURE_ACTION     default: sets errno to ENOMEM, or no-op on win32
00310   The action to take before "return 0" when malloc fails to be able to
00311   return memory because there is none available.
00312 
00313 HAVE_MORECORE             default: 1 (true) unless win32 or ONLY_MSPACES
00314   True if this system supports sbrk or an emulation of it.
00315 
00316 MORECORE                  default: sbrk
00317   The name of the sbrk-style system routine to call to obtain more
00318   memory.  See below for guidance on writing custom MORECORE
00319   functions. The type of the argument to sbrk/MORECORE varies across
00320   systems.  It cannot be size_t, because it supports negative
00321   arguments, so it is normally the signed type of the same width as
00322   size_t (sometimes declared as "intptr_t").  It doesn't much matter
00323   though. Internally, we only call it with arguments less than half
00324   the max value of a size_t, which should work across all reasonable
00325   possibilities, although sometimes generating compiler warnings.
00326 
00327 MORECORE_CONTIGUOUS       default: 1 (true) if HAVE_MORECORE
00328   If true, take advantage of fact that consecutive calls to MORECORE
00329   with positive arguments always return contiguous increasing
00330   addresses.  This is true of unix sbrk. It does not hurt too much to
00331   set it true anyway, since malloc copes with non-contiguities.
00332   Setting it false when definitely non-contiguous saves time
00333   and possibly wasted space it would take to discover this though.
00334 
00335 MORECORE_CANNOT_TRIM      default: NOT defined
00336   True if MORECORE cannot release space back to the system when given
00337   negative arguments. This is generally necessary only if you are
00338   using a hand-crafted MORECORE function that cannot handle negative
00339   arguments.
00340 
00341 NO_SEGMENT_TRAVERSAL       default: 0
00342   If non-zero, suppresses traversals of memory segments
00343   returned by either MORECORE or CALL_MMAP. This disables
00344   merging of segments that are contiguous, and selectively
00345   releasing them to the OS if unused, but bounds execution times.
00346 
00347 HAVE_MMAP                 default: 1 (true)
00348   True if this system supports mmap or an emulation of it.  If so, and
00349   HAVE_MORECORE is not true, MMAP is used for all system
00350   allocation. If set and HAVE_MORECORE is true as well, MMAP is
00351   primarily used to directly allocate very large blocks. It is also
00352   used as a backup strategy in cases where MORECORE fails to provide
00353   space from system. Note: A single call to MUNMAP is assumed to be
00354   able to unmap memory that may have be allocated using multiple calls
00355   to MMAP, so long as they are adjacent.
00356 
00357 HAVE_MREMAP               default: 1 on linux, else 0
00358   If true realloc() uses mremap() to re-allocate large blocks and
00359   extend or shrink allocation spaces.
00360 
00361 MMAP_CLEARS               default: 1 except on WINCE.
00362   True if mmap clears memory so calloc doesn't need to. This is true
00363   for standard unix mmap using /dev/zero and on WIN32 except for WINCE.
00364 
00365 USE_BUILTIN_FFS            default: 0 (i.e., not used)
00366   Causes malloc to use the builtin ffs() function to compute indices.
00367   Some compilers may recognize and intrinsify ffs to be faster than the
00368   supplied C version. Also, the case of x86 using gcc is special-cased
00369   to an asm instruction, so is already as fast as it can be, and so
00370   this setting has no effect. Similarly for Win32 under recent MS compilers.
00371   (On most x86s, the asm version is only slightly faster than the C version.)
00372 
00373 malloc_getpagesize         default: derive from system includes, or 4096.
00374   The system page size. To the extent possible, this malloc manages
00375   memory from the system in page-size units.  This may be (and
00376   usually is) a function rather than a constant. This is ignored
00377   if WIN32, where page size is determined using getSystemInfo during
00378   initialization. This may be several megabytes if ENABLE_LARGE_PAGES
00379   is enabled.
00380 
00381 ENABLE_LARGE_PAGES         default: NOT defined
00382   Causes the system page size to be the value of GetLargePageMinimum()
00383   if that function is available (Windows Server 2003/Vista or later)
00384   or gethugepagesize() if the libhugetlbfs library is loaded into this
00385   process (Linux, BSD and others, see http://libhugetlbfs.sourceforge.net/).
00386   This allows the use of large page entries in the MMU which can
00387   significantly improve performance in large working set applications
00388   as TLB cache load is reduced by a factor of three. Note that on Windows
00389   enabling this option is equal to locking the process' memory in current
00390   implementations of Windows and requires the SE_LOCK_MEMORY_PRIVILEGE
00391   to be held by the process in order to succeed. For POSIX to make
00392   large page support work you need to link against libhugetlbfs, otherwise
00393   support silently disables itself.
00394 
00395 USE_DEV_RANDOM             default: 0 (i.e., not used)
00396   Causes malloc to use /dev/random to initialize secure magic seed for
00397   stamping footers. Otherwise, the current time is used.
00398 
00399 NO_MALLINFO                default: 0
00400   If defined, don't compile "mallinfo". This can be a simple way
00401   of dealing with mismatches between system declarations and
00402   those in this file.
00403 
00404 MALLINFO_FIELD_TYPE        default: size_t
00405   The type of the fields in the mallinfo struct. This was originally
00406   defined as "int" in SVID etc, but is more usefully defined as
00407   size_t. The value is used only if  HAVE_USR_INCLUDE_MALLOC_H is not set
00408 
00409 REALLOC_ZERO_BYTES_FREES    default: not defined
00410   This should be set if a call to realloc with zero bytes should
00411   be the same as a call to free. Some people think it should. Otherwise,
00412   since this malloc returns a unique pointer for malloc(0), so does
00413   realloc(p, 0).
00414 
00415 LACKS_UNISTD_H, LACKS_FCNTL_H, LACKS_SYS_PARAM_H, LACKS_SYS_MMAN_H
00416 LACKS_STRINGS_H, LACKS_STRING_H, LACKS_SYS_TYPES_H,  LACKS_ERRNO_H
00417 LACKS_STDLIB_H                default: NOT defined unless on WIN32
00418   Define these if your system does not have these header files.
00419   You might need to manually insert some of the declarations they provide.
00420 
00421 DEFAULT_GRANULARITY        default: page size if MORECORE_CONTIGUOUS,
00422                                 system_info.dwAllocationGranularity in WIN32,
00423                                 GetLargePageMinimum() if ENABLE_LARGE_PAGES,
00424                                 otherwise 64K.
00425       Also settable using mallopt(M_GRANULARITY, x)
00426   The unit for allocating and deallocating memory from the system.  On
00427   most systems with contiguous MORECORE, there is no reason to
00428   make this more than a page. However, systems with MMAP tend to
00429   either require or encourage larger granularities.  You can increase
00430   this value to prevent system allocation functions to be called so
00431   often, especially if they are slow.  The value must be at least one
00432   page and must be a power of two.  Setting to 0 causes initialization
00433   to either page size or win32 region size.  (Note: In previous
00434   versions of malloc, the equivalent of this option was called
00435   "TOP_PAD")
00436 
00437 DEFAULT_GRANULARITY_ALIGNED default: undefined (which means page size)
00438   Whether to enforce alignment when allocating and deallocating memory
00439   from the system i.e. the base address of all allocations will be
00440   aligned to DEFAULT_GRANULARITY if it is set. Note that enabling this carries
00441   some overhead as multiple calls must now be made when probing for a valid
00442   aligned value, however it does greatly ease the checking for whether
00443   a given memory pointer was allocated by this allocator rather than
00444   some other.
00445 
00446 DEFAULT_TRIM_THRESHOLD    default: 2MB
00447       Also settable using mallopt(M_TRIM_THRESHOLD, x)
00448   The maximum amount of unused top-most memory to keep before
00449   releasing via malloc_trim in free().  Automatic trimming is mainly
00450   useful in long-lived programs using contiguous MORECORE.  Because
00451   trimming via sbrk can be slow on some systems, and can sometimes be
00452   wasteful (in cases where programs immediately afterward allocate
00453   more large chunks) the value should be high enough so that your
00454   overall system performance would improve by releasing this much
00455   memory.  As a rough guide, you might set to a value close to the
00456   average size of a process (program) running on your system.
00457   Releasing this much memory would allow such a process to run in
00458   memory.  Generally, it is worth tuning trim thresholds when a
00459   program undergoes phases where several large chunks are allocated
00460   and released in ways that can reuse each other's storage, perhaps
00461   mixed with phases where there are no such chunks at all. The trim
00462   value must be greater than page size to have any useful effect.  To
00463   disable trimming completely, you can set to MAX_SIZE_T. Note that the trick
00464   some people use of mallocing a huge space and then freeing it at
00465   program startup, in an attempt to reserve system memory, doesn't
00466   have the intended effect under automatic trimming, since that memory
00467   will immediately be returned to the system.
00468 
00469 DEFAULT_MMAP_THRESHOLD       default: 256K
00470       Also settable using mallopt(M_MMAP_THRESHOLD, x)
00471   The request size threshold for using MMAP to directly service a
00472   request. Requests of at least this size that cannot be allocated
00473   using already-existing space will be serviced via mmap.  (If enough
00474   normal freed space already exists it is used instead.)  Using mmap
00475   segregates relatively large chunks of memory so that they can be
00476   individually obtained and released from the host system. A request
00477   serviced through mmap is never reused by any other request (at least
00478   not directly; the system may just so happen to remap successive
00479   requests to the same locations).  Segregating space in this way has
00480   the benefits that: Mmapped space can always be individually released
00481   back to the system, which helps keep the system level memory demands
00482   of a long-lived program low.  Also, mapped memory doesn't become
00483   `locked' between other chunks, as can happen with normally allocated
00484   chunks, which means that even trimming via malloc_trim would not
00485   release them.  However, it has the disadvantage that the space
00486   cannot be reclaimed, consolidated, and then used to service later
00487   requests, as happens with normal chunks.  The advantages of mmap
00488   nearly always outweigh disadvantages for "large" chunks, but the
00489   value of "large" may vary across systems.  The default is an
00490   empirically derived value that works well in most systems. You can
00491   disable mmap by setting to MAX_SIZE_T.
00492 
00493 MAX_RELEASE_CHECK_RATE   default: 4095 unless not HAVE_MMAP
00494   The number of consolidated frees between checks to release
00495   unused segments when freeing. When using non-contiguous segments,
00496   especially with multiple mspaces, checking only for topmost space
00497   doesn't always suffice to trigger trimming. To compensate for this,
00498   free() will, with a period of MAX_RELEASE_CHECK_RATE (or the
00499   current number of segments, if greater) try to release unused
00500   segments to the OS when freeing chunks that result in
00501   consolidation. The best value for this parameter is a compromise
00502   between slowing down frees with relatively costly checks that
00503   rarely trigger versus holding on to unused memory. To effectively
00504   disable, set to MAX_SIZE_T. This may lead to a very slight speed
00505   improvement at the expense of carrying around more memory.
00506 */
00507 
00508 /* Version identifier to allow people to support multiple versions */
00509 #ifndef DLMALLOC_VERSION
00510 #define DLMALLOC_VERSION 20804
00511 #endif /* DLMALLOC_VERSION */
00512

00687 /*
00688   malloc2 flag options. These non-portable functions provide
00689   additional functionality beyond those traditionally provided by
00690   a memory allocator. You may pass custom flags in the bits
00691   specified by M2_CUSTOM_FLAGS_MASK.
00692 */
00693 
00694 #ifndef M2_FLAGS_DEFINED
00695 #define M2_FLAGS_DEFINED
00696 
00697 #define M2_ZERO_MEMORY          (1<<0)
00698 #define M2_PREVENT_MOVE         (1<<1)
00699 #define M2_ALWAYS_MMAP          (1<<2)
00700 #define M2_RESERVED1            (1<<3)
00701 #define M2_RESERVED2            (1<<4)
00702 #define M2_RESERVED3            (1<<5)
00703 #define M2_RESERVED4            (1<<6)
00704 #define M2_RESERVED5            (1<<7)
00705 #define M2_RESERVE_ISMULTIPLIER (1<<15)
00706 /* 7 bits is given to the address reservation specifier.
00707 This lets you set a multiplier (bit 15 set) or a 1<< shift value.
00708 */
00709 #define M2_RESERVE_MASK         0x00007f00
00710 #define M2_RESERVE_MULT(n)      (M2_RESERVE_ISMULTIPLIER|(((n)<<8)&M2_RESERVE_MASK))
00711 #define M2_RESERVE_SHIFT(n)     (((n)<<8)&M2_RESERVE_MASK)
00712 #define M2_FLAGS_MASK           0x0000ffff
00713 #define M2_CUSTOM_FLAGS_BEGIN   (1<<16)
00714 #define M2_CUSTOM_FLAGS_MASK    0xffff0000
00715 
00716 #endif /* M2_FLAGS_DEFINED */

00718 /*
00719   mallopt tuning options.  SVID/XPG defines four standard parameter
00720   numbers for mallopt, normally defined in malloc.h.  None of these
00721   are used in this malloc, so setting them has no effect. But this
00722   malloc does support the following options.
00723 */
00724 
00725 #define M_TRIM_THRESHOLD     (-1)
00726 #define M_GRANULARITY        (-2)
00727 #define M_MMAP_THRESHOLD     (-3)

00729 /* ------------------------ Mallinfo declarations ------------------------ */
00730 
00731 #if !NO_MALLINFO
00732 /*
00733   This version of malloc supports the standard SVID/XPG mallinfo
00734   routine that returns a struct containing usage properties and
00735   statistics. It should work on any system that has a
00736   /usr/include/malloc.h defining struct mallinfo.  The main
00737   declaration needed is the mallinfo struct that is returned (by-copy)
00738   by mallinfo().  The malloinfo struct contains a bunch of fields that
00739   are not even meaningful in this version of malloc.  These fields are
00740   are instead filled by mallinfo() with other numbers that might be of
00741   interest.
00742 
00743   HAVE_USR_INCLUDE_MALLOC_H should be set if you have a
00744   /usr/include/malloc.h file that includes a declaration of struct
00745   mallinfo.  If so, it is included; else a compliant version is
00746   declared below.  These must be precisely the same for mallinfo() to
00747   work.  The original SVID version of this struct, defined on most
00748   systems with mallinfo, declares all fields as ints. But some others
00749   define as unsigned long. If your system defines the fields using a
00750   type of different width than listed here, you MUST #include your
00751   system version and #define HAVE_USR_INCLUDE_MALLOC_H.
00752 */
00753 
00754 /* #define HAVE_USR_INCLUDE_MALLOC_H */
00755 
00756 #ifdef HAVE_USR_INCLUDE_MALLOC_H
00757 #include "/usr/include/malloc.h"
00758 #else /* HAVE_USR_INCLUDE_MALLOC_H */
00759 #ifndef STRUCT_MALLINFO_DECLARED
00760 #define STRUCT_MALLINFO_DECLARED 1
00761 struct mallinfo {
00762   MALLINFO_FIELD_TYPE arena;    /* non-mmapped space allocated from system */
00763   MALLINFO_FIELD_TYPE ordblks;  /* number of free chunks */
00764   MALLINFO_FIELD_TYPE smblks;   /* always 0 */
00765   MALLINFO_FIELD_TYPE hblks;    /* always 0 */
00766   MALLINFO_FIELD_TYPE hblkhd;   /* space in mmapped regions */
00767   MALLINFO_FIELD_TYPE usmblks;  /* maximum total allocated space */
00768   MALLINFO_FIELD_TYPE fsmblks;  /* always 0 */
00769   MALLINFO_FIELD_TYPE uordblks; /* total allocated space */
00770   MALLINFO_FIELD_TYPE fordblks; /* total free space */
00771   MALLINFO_FIELD_TYPE keepcost; /* releasable (via malloc_trim) space */
00772 };
00773 #endif /* STRUCT_MALLINFO_DECLARED */
00774 #endif /* HAVE_USR_INCLUDE_MALLOC_H */
00775 #endif /* NO_MALLINFO */
00776 
00777 /*
00778   Try to persuade compilers to inline. The most critical functions for
00779   inlining are defined as macros, so these aren't used for them.
00780 */
00781 
00782 #ifndef FORCEINLINE
00783   #if defined(__GNUC__)
00784 #define FORCEINLINE __inline __attribute__ ((always_inline))
00785   #elif defined(_MSC_VER)
00786     #define FORCEINLINE __forceinline
00787   #endif
00788 #endif
00789 #ifndef NOINLINE
00790   #if defined(__GNUC__)
00791     #define NOINLINE __attribute__ ((noinline))
00792   #elif defined(_MSC_VER)
00793     #define NOINLINE __declspec(noinline)
00794   #else
00795     #define NOINLINE
00796   #endif
00797 #endif
00798 
00799 #ifdef __cplusplus
00800 extern "C" {
00801 #ifndef FORCEINLINE
00802  #define FORCEINLINE inline
00803 #endif
00804 #endif /* __cplusplus */
00805 #ifndef FORCEINLINE
00806  #define FORCEINLINE
00807 #endif

00811 /* ------------------- Declarations of public routines ------------------- */
00812 
00813 #ifndef USE_DL_PREFIX
00814 #define dlcalloc               calloc
00815 #define dlfree                 free
00816 #define dlmalloc               malloc
00817 #define dlmemalign             memalign
00818 #define dlrealloc              realloc
00819 #define dlvalloc               valloc
00820 #define dlpvalloc              pvalloc
00821 #define dlmallinfo             mallinfo
00822 #define dlmallopt              mallopt
00823 #define dlmalloc_trim          malloc_trim
00824 #define dlmalloc_stats         malloc_stats
00825 #define dlmalloc_usable_size   malloc_usable_size
00826 #define dlmalloc_footprint     malloc_footprint
00827 #define dlmalloc_max_footprint malloc_max_footprint
00828 #define dlindependent_calloc   independent_calloc
00829 #define dlindependent_comalloc independent_comalloc
00830 #endif /* USE_DL_PREFIX */

00832 
00833 /*
00834   malloc(size_t n)
00835   Returns a pointer to a newly allocated chunk of at least n bytes, or
00836   null if no space is available, in which case errno is set to ENOMEM
00837   on ANSI C systems.
00838 
00839   If n is zero, malloc returns a minimum-sized chunk. (The minimum
00840   size is 16 bytes on most 32bit systems, and 32 bytes on 64bit
00841   systems.)  Note that size_t is an unsigned type, so calls with
00842   arguments that would be negative if signed are interpreted as
00843   requests for huge amounts of space, which will often fail. The
00844   maximum supported value of n differs across systems, but is in all
00845   cases less than the maximum representable value of a size_t.
00846 */
00847 void* dlmalloc(size_t);
00848 
00849 /*
00850   free(void* p)
00851   Releases the chunk of memory pointed to by p, that had been previously
00852   allocated using malloc or a related routine such as realloc.
00853   It has no effect if p is null. If p was not malloced or already
00854   freed, free(p) will by default cause the current program to abort.
00855 */
00856 void  dlfree(void*);
00857 
00858 /*
00859   calloc(size_t n_elements, size_t element_size);
00860   Returns a pointer to n_elements * element_size bytes, with all locations
00861   set to zero.
00862 */
00863 void* dlcalloc(size_t, size_t);
00864 
00865 /*
00866   realloc(void* p, size_t n)
00867   Returns a pointer to a chunk of size n that contains the same data
00868   as does chunk p up to the minimum of (n, p's size) bytes, or null
00869   if no space is available.
00870 
00871   The returned pointer may or may not be the same as p. The algorithm
00872   prefers extending p in most cases when possible, otherwise it
00873   employs the equivalent of a malloc-copy-free sequence.
00874 
00875   If p is null, realloc is equivalent to malloc.
00876 
00877   If space is not available, realloc returns null, errno is set (if on
00878   ANSI) and p is NOT freed.
00879 
00880   if n is for fewer bytes than already held by p, the newly unused
00881   space is lopped off and freed if possible.  realloc with a size
00882   argument of zero (re)allocates a minimum-sized chunk.
00883 
00884   The old unix realloc convention of allowing the last-free'd chunk
00885   to be used as an argument to realloc is not supported.
00886 */
00887 
00888 void* dlrealloc(void*, size_t);
00889 
00890 /*
00891   memalign(size_t alignment, size_t n);
00892   Returns a pointer to a newly allocated chunk of n bytes, aligned
00893   in accord with the alignment argument.
00894 
00895   The alignment argument should be a power of two. If the argument is
00896   not a power of two, the nearest greater power is used.
00897   8-byte alignment is guaranteed by normal malloc calls, so don't
00898   bother calling memalign with an argument of 8 or less.
00899 
00900   Overreliance on memalign is a sure way to fragment space.
00901 */
00902 void* dlmemalign(size_t, size_t);
00903 
00904 /*
00905   valloc(size_t n);
00906   Equivalent to memalign(pagesize, n), where pagesize is the page
00907   size of the system. If the pagesize is unknown, 4096 is used.
00908 */
00909 void* dlvalloc(size_t);
00910 
00911 /*
00912   mallopt(int parameter_number, int parameter_value)
00913   Sets tunable parameters The format is to provide a
00914   (parameter-number, parameter-value) pair.  mallopt then sets the
00915   corresponding parameter to the argument value if it can (i.e., so
00916   long as the value is meaningful), and returns 1 if successful else
00917   0.  To workaround the fact that mallopt is specified to use int,
00918   not size_t parameters, the value -1 is specially treated as the
00919   maximum unsigned size_t value.
00920 
00921   SVID/XPG/ANSI defines four standard param numbers for mallopt,
00922   normally defined in malloc.h.  None of these are use in this malloc,
00923   so setting them has no effect. But this malloc also supports other
00924   options in mallopt. See below for details.  Briefly, supported
00925   parameters are as follows (listed defaults are for "typical"
00926   configurations).
00927 
00928   Symbol            param #  default    allowed param values
00929   M_TRIM_THRESHOLD     -1   2*1024*1024   any   (-1 disables)
00930   M_GRANULARITY        -2     page size   any power of 2 >= page size
00931   M_MMAP_THRESHOLD     -3      256*1024   any   (or 0 if no MMAP support)
00932 */
00933 int dlmallopt(int, int);
00934 
00935 /*
00936   malloc_footprint();
00937   Returns the number of bytes obtained from the system.  The total
00938   number of bytes allocated by malloc, realloc etc., is less than this
00939   value. Unlike mallinfo, this function returns only a precomputed
00940   result, so can be called frequently to monitor memory consumption.
00941   Even if locks are otherwise defined, this function does not use them,
00942   so results might not be up to date.
00943 */
00944 size_t dlmalloc_footprint(void);
00945 
00946 /*
00947   malloc_max_footprint();
00948   Returns the maximum number of bytes obtained from the system. This
00949   value will be greater than current footprint if deallocated space
00950   has been reclaimed by the system. The peak number of bytes allocated
00951   by malloc, realloc etc., is less than this value. Unlike mallinfo,
00952   this function returns only a precomputed result, so can be called
00953   frequently to monitor memory consumption.  Even if locks are
00954   otherwise defined, this function does not use them, so results might
00955   not be up to date.
00956 */
00957 size_t dlmalloc_max_footprint(void);
00958 
00959 #if !NO_MALLINFO
00960 /*
00961   mallinfo()
00962   Returns (by copy) a struct containing various summary statistics:
00963 
00964   arena:     current total non-mmapped bytes allocated from system
00965   ordblks:   the number of free chunks
00966   smblks:    always zero.
00967   hblks:     current number of mmapped regions
00968   hblkhd:    total bytes held in mmapped regions
00969   usmblks:   the maximum total allocated space. This will be greater
00970                 than current total if trimming has occurred.
00971   fsmblks:   always zero
00972   uordblks:  current total allocated space (normal or mmapped)
00973   fordblks:  total free space
00974   keepcost:  the maximum number of bytes that could ideally be released
00975                back to system via malloc_trim. ("ideally" means that
00976                it ignores page restrictions etc.)
00977 
00978   Because these fields are ints, but internal bookkeeping may
00979   be kept as longs, the reported values may wrap around zero and
00980   thus be inaccurate.
00981 */
00982 struct mallinfo dlmallinfo(void);
00983 #endif /* NO_MALLINFO */
00984 
00985 /*
00986   independent_calloc(size_t n_elements, size_t element_size, void* chunks[]);
00987 
00988   independent_calloc is similar to calloc, but instead of returning a
00989   single cleared space, it returns an array of pointers to n_elements
00990   independent elements that can hold contents of size elem_size, each
00991   of which starts out cleared, and can be independently freed,
00992   realloc'ed etc. The elements are guaranteed to be adjacently
00993   allocated (this is not guaranteed to occur with multiple callocs or
00994   mallocs), which may also improve cache locality in some
00995   applications.
00996 
00997   The "chunks" argument is optional (i.e., may be null, which is
00998   probably the most typical usage). If it is null, the returned array
00999   is itself dynamically allocated and should also be freed when it is
01000   no longer needed. Otherwise, the chunks array must be of at least
01001   n_elements in length. It is filled in with the pointers to the
01002   chunks.
01003 
01004   In either case, independent_calloc returns this pointer array, or
01005   null if the allocation failed.  If n_elements is zero and "chunks"
01006   is null, it returns a chunk representing an array with zero elements
01007   (which should be freed if not wanted).
01008 
01009   Each element must be individually freed when it is no longer
01010   needed. If you'd like to instead be able to free all at once, you
01011   should instead use regular calloc and assign pointers into this
01012   space to represent elements.  (In this case though, you cannot
01013   independently free elements.)
01014 
01015   independent_calloc simplifies and speeds up implementations of many
01016   kinds of pools.  It may also be useful when constructing large data
01017   structures that initially have a fixed number of fixed-sized nodes,
01018   but the number is not known at compile time, and some of the nodes
01019   may later need to be freed. For example:
01020 
01021   struct Node { int item; struct Node* next; };
01022 
01023   struct Node* build_list() {
01024     struct Node** pool;
01025     int n = read_number_of_nodes_needed();
01026     if (n <= 0) return 0;
01027     pool = (struct Node**)(independent_calloc(n, sizeof(struct Node), 0);
01028     if (pool == 0) die();
01029     // organize into a linked list...
01030     struct Node* first = pool[0];
01031     for (i = 0; i < n-1; ++i)
01032       pool[i]->next = pool[i+1];
01033     free(pool);     // Can now free the array (or not, if it is needed later)
01034     return first;
01035   }
01036 */
01037 void** dlindependent_calloc(size_t, size_t, void**);
01038 
01039 /*
01040   independent_comalloc(size_t n_elements, size_t sizes[], void* chunks[]);
01041 
01042   independent_comalloc allocates, all at once, a set of n_elements
01043   chunks with sizes indicated in the "sizes" array.    It returns
01044   an array of pointers to these elements, each of which can be
01045   independently freed, realloc'ed etc. The elements are guaranteed to
01046   be adjacently allocated (this is not guaranteed to occur with
01047   multiple callocs or mallocs), which may also improve cache locality
01048   in some applications.
01049 
01050   The "chunks" argument is optional (i.e., may be null). If it is null
01051   the returned array is itself dynamically allocated and should also
01052   be freed when it is no longer needed. Otherwise, the chunks array
01053   must be of at least n_elements in length. It is filled in with the
01054   pointers to the chunks.
01055 
01056   In either case, independent_comalloc returns this pointer array, or
01057   null if the allocation failed.  If n_elements is zero and chunks is
01058   null, it returns a chunk representing an array with zero elements
01059   (which should be freed if not wanted).
01060 
01061   Each element must be individually freed when it is no longer
01062   needed. If you'd like to instead be able to free all at once, you
01063   should instead use a single regular malloc, and assign pointers at
01064   particular offsets in the aggregate space. (In this case though, you
01065   cannot independently free elements.)
01066 
01067   independent_comallac differs from independent_calloc in that each
01068   element may have a different size, and also that it does not
01069   automatically clear elements.
01070 
01071   independent_comalloc can be used to speed up allocation in cases
01072   where several structs or objects must always be allocated at the
01073   same time.  For example:
01074 
01075   struct Head { ... }
01076   struct Foot { ... }
01077 
01078   void send_message(char* msg) {
01079     int msglen = strlen(msg);
01080     size_t sizes[3] = { sizeof(struct Head), msglen, sizeof(struct Foot) };
01081     void* chunks[3];
01082     if (independent_comalloc(3, sizes, chunks) == 0)
01083       die();
01084     struct Head* head = (struct Head*)(chunks[0]);
01085     char*        body = (char*)(chunks[1]);
01086     struct Foot* foot = (struct Foot*)(chunks[2]);
01087     // ...
01088   }
01089 
01090   In general though, independent_comalloc is worth using only for
01091   larger values of n_elements. For small values, you probably won't
01092   detect enough difference from series of malloc calls to bother.
01093 
01094   Overuse of independent_comalloc can increase overall memory usage,
01095   since it cannot reuse existing noncontiguous small chunks that
01096   might be available for some of the elements.
01097 */
01098 void** dlindependent_comalloc(size_t, size_t*, void**);
01099 
01100 
01101 /*
01102   pvalloc(size_t n);
01103   Equivalent to valloc(minimum-page-that-holds(n)), that is,
01104   round up n to nearest pagesize.
01105  */
01106 void*  dlpvalloc(size_t);
01107 
01108 /*
01109   malloc_trim(size_t pad);
01110 
01111   If possible, gives memory back to the system (via negative arguments
01112   to sbrk) if there is unused memory at the `high' end of the malloc
01113   pool or in unused MMAP segments. You can call this after freeing
01114   large blocks of memory to potentially reduce the system-level memory
01115   requirements of a program. However, it cannot guarantee to reduce
01116   memory. Under some allocation patterns, some large free blocks of
01117   memory will be locked between two used chunks, so they cannot be
01118   given back to the system.
01119 
01120   The `pad' argument to malloc_trim represents the amount of free
01121   trailing space to leave untrimmed. If this argument is zero, only
01122   the minimum amount of memory to maintain internal data structures
01123   will be left. Non-zero arguments can be supplied to maintain enough
01124   trailing space to service future expected allocations without having
01125   to re-obtain memory from the system.
01126 
01127   Malloc_trim returns 1 if it actually released any memory, else 0.
01128 */
01129 int  dlmalloc_trim(size_t);
01130 
01131 /*
01132   malloc_stats();
01133   Prints on stderr the amount of space obtained from the system (both
01134   via sbrk and mmap), the maximum amount (which may be more than
01135   current if malloc_trim and/or munmap got called), and the current
01136   number of bytes allocated via malloc (or realloc, etc) but not yet
01137   freed. Note that this is the number of bytes allocated, not the
01138   number requested. It will be larger than the number requested
01139   because of alignment and bookkeeping overhead. Because it includes
01140   alignment wastage as being in use, this figure may be greater than
01141   zero even when no user-level chunks are allocated.
01142 
01143   The reported current and maximum system memory can be inaccurate if
01144   a program makes other calls to system memory allocation functions
01145   (normally sbrk) outside of malloc.
01146 
01147   malloc_stats prints only the most commonly interesting statistics.
01148   More information can be obtained by calling mallinfo.
01149 */
01150 void  dlmalloc_stats(void);
01151 
01152 #endif /* ONLY_MSPACES */
01153 
01154 /*
01155   malloc_usable_size(void* p);
01156 
01157   Returns the number of bytes you can actually use in
01158   an allocated chunk, which may be more than you requested (although
01159   often not) due to alignment and minimum size constraints.
01160   You can use this many bytes without worrying about
01161   overwriting other allocated objects. This is not a particularly great
01162   programming practice. malloc_usable_size can be more useful in
01163   debugging and assertions, for example:
01164 
01165   p = malloc(n);
01166   assert(malloc_usable_size(p) >= 256);
01167 */
01168 size_t dlmalloc_usable_size(void*);
01169 
01170 
01171 #if MSPACES
01172 
01173 /*
01174   mspace is an opaque type representing an independent
01175   region of space that supports mspace_malloc, etc.
01176 */
01177 typedef void* mspace;
01178 
01179 /*
01180   create_mspace creates and returns a new independent space with the
01181   given initial capacity, or, if 0, the default granularity size.  It
01182   returns null if there is no system memory available to create the
01183   space.  If argument locked is non-zero, the space uses a separate
01184   lock to control access. The capacity of the space will grow
01185   dynamically as needed to service mspace_malloc requests.  You can
01186   control the sizes of incremental increases of this space by
01187   compiling with a different DEFAULT_GRANULARITY or dynamically
01188   setting with mallopt(M_GRANULARITY, value).
01189 */
01190 mspace create_mspace(size_t capacity, int locked);
01191 
01192 /*
01193   destroy_mspace destroys the given space, and attempts to return all
01194   of its memory back to the system, returning the total number of
01195   bytes freed. After destruction, the results of access to all memory
01196   used by the space become undefined.
01197 */
01198 size_t destroy_mspace(mspace msp);
01199 
01200 /*
01201   create_mspace_with_base uses the memory supplied as the initial base
01202   of a new mspace. Part (less than 128*sizeof(size_t) bytes) of this
01203   space is used for bookkeeping, so the capacity must be at least this
01204   large. (Otherwise 0 is returned.) When this initial space is
01205   exhausted, additional memory will be obtained from the system.
01206   Destroying this space will deallocate all additionally allocated
01207   space (if possible) but not the initial base.
01208 */
01209 mspace create_mspace_with_base(void* base, size_t capacity, int locked);
01210 
01211 /*
01212   mspace_track_large_chunks controls whether requests for large chunks
01213   are allocated in their own untracked mmapped regions, separate from
01214   others in this mspace. By default large chunks are not tracked,
01215   which reduces fragmentation. However, such chunks are not
01216   necessarily released to the system upon destroy_mspace.  Enabling
01217   tracking by setting to true may increase fragmentation, but avoids
01218   leakage when relying on destroy_mspace to release all memory
01219   allocated using this space.  The function returns the previous
01220   setting.
01221 */
01222 int mspace_track_large_chunks(mspace msp, int enable);
01223 
01224 
01225 /*
01226   mspace_malloc behaves as malloc, but operates within
01227   the given space.
01228 */
01229 void* mspace_malloc(mspace msp, size_t bytes);
01230 
01231 /*
01232   mspace_free behaves as free, but operates within
01233   the given space.
01234 
01235   If compiled with FOOTERS==1, mspace_free is not actually needed.
01236   free may be called instead of mspace_free because freed chunks from
01237   any space are handled by their originating spaces.
01238 */
01239 void mspace_free(mspace msp, void* mem);
01240 
01241 /*
01242   mspace_realloc behaves as realloc, but operates within
01243   the given space.
01244 
01245   If compiled with FOOTERS==1, mspace_realloc is not actually
01246   needed.  realloc may be called instead of mspace_realloc because
01247   realloced chunks from any space are handled by their originating
01248   spaces.
01249 */
01250 void* mspace_realloc(mspace msp, void* mem, size_t newsize);
01251 
01252 /*
01253   mspace_calloc behaves as calloc, but operates within
01254   the given space.
01255 */
01256 void* mspace_calloc(mspace msp, size_t n_elements, size_t elem_size);
01257 
01258 /*
01259   mspace_memalign behaves as memalign, but operates within
01260   the given space.
01261 */
01262 void* mspace_memalign(mspace msp, size_t alignment, size_t bytes);
01263 
01264 /*
01265   mspace_independent_calloc behaves as independent_calloc, but
01266   operates within the given space.
01267 */
01268 void** mspace_independent_calloc(mspace msp, size_t n_elements,
01269                                  size_t elem_size, void* chunks[]);
01270 
01271 /*
01272   mspace_independent_comalloc behaves as independent_comalloc, but
01273   operates within the given space.
01274 */
01275 void** mspace_independent_comalloc(mspace msp, size_t n_elements,
01276                                    size_t sizes[], void* chunks[]);
01277 
01278 /*
01279   mspace_malloc2 behaves as mspace_malloc, but provides additional
01280   functionality. Setting alignment to a non-zero value is
01281   identical to using mspace_memalign(). Flags may be set to:
01282 
01283   * M2_ZERO_MEMORY:      Sets the contents of the allocated chunk to
01284                          zero.
01285   * M2_ALWAYS_MMAP:      Always allocate as though mmap_threshold
01286                          were being exceeded. This is useful for large
01287                          arrays which frequently extend.
01288   * M2_RESERVE_MULT(n):  Reserve n times as much address space such
01289                          that mmapped realloc() is much faster.
01290   * M2_RESERVE_SHIFT(n): Reserve (1<<n) bytes of address space such
01291                          that mmapped realloc() is much faster.
01292 
01293   Note when setting RESERVE sizes that on some platforms (e.g. Windows)
01294   page tables are constructed for the reservation size. On x86/x64
01295   Windows this costs 2Kb of kernel memory per Mb reserved, and as on
01296   x86 kernel memory is not abundant you should not be excessive.
01297 */
01298 void* mspace_malloc2(mspace msp, size_t bytes, size_t alignment, unsigned flags);
01299 
01300 /*
01301   mspace_realloc2 behaves as mspace_realloc, but provides additional
01302   functionality. Setting alignment to a non-zero value is
01303   identical to using mspace_memalign(). Flags may be set to:
01304 
01305   * M2_ZERO_MEMORY:      Sets any increase in the allocated chunk to
01306                          zero. Note that this zeroes only the increase
01307                          from what dlmalloc thinks the chunk's size is,
01308                          so if you didn't use this flag when allocating
01309                          with malloc2 (which zeroes up to chunk size)
01310                          then you may have garbage just before the new
01311                          space.
01312   * M2_PREVENT_MOVE:     Prevent moves in realloc2() which is very
01313                          useful for C++ container objects.
01314   * M2_ALWAYS_MMAP:      Always allocate as though mmap_threshold
01315                          were being exceeded. Note that setting this
01316                          bit will not necessarily mmap a chunk which
01317                          isn't already mmapped, but it will force a
01318                          mmapped chunk if new memory needs allocating.
01319   * M2_RESERVE_MULT(n):  Reserve n times as much address space such
01320                          that mmapped realloc() is much faster.
01321   * M2_RESERVE_SHIFT(n): Reserve (1<<n) bytes of address space such
01322                          that mmapped realloc() is much faster.
01323 
01324   Note when setting RESERVE sizes that on some platforms (e.g. Windows)
01325   page tables are constructed for the reservation size. On x86/x64
01326   Windows this costs 2Kb of kernel memory per Mb reserved, and as on
01327   x86 kernel memory is not abundant you should not be excessive.
01328   With regard to M2_RESERVE_*, these only take effect when the
01329   mmapped chunk has exceeded its reservation space and a new
01330   reservation space needs to be created.
01331 */
01332 void* mspace_realloc2(mspace msp, void* mem, size_t newsize, size_t alignment, unsigned flags);
01333 
01334 /*
01335   mspace_footprint() returns the number of bytes obtained from the
01336   system for this space.
01337 */
01338 size_t mspace_footprint(mspace msp);
01339 
01340 /*
01341   mspace_max_footprint() returns the peak number of bytes obtained from the
01342   system for this space.
01343 */
01344 size_t mspace_max_footprint(mspace msp);
01345 
01346 
01347 #if !NO_MALLINFO
01348 /*
01349   mspace_mallinfo behaves as mallinfo, but reports properties of
01350   the given space.
01351 */
01352 struct mallinfo mspace_mallinfo(mspace msp);
01353 #endif /* NO_MALLINFO */
01354 
01355 /*
01356   malloc_usable_size(void* p) behaves the same as malloc_usable_size;
01357 */
01358   size_t mspace_usable_size(void* mem);
01359 
01360 /*
01361   mspace_malloc_stats behaves as malloc_stats, but reports
01362   properties of the given space.
01363 */
01364 void mspace_malloc_stats(mspace msp);
01365 
01366 /*
01367   mspace_trim behaves as malloc_trim, but
01368   operates within the given space.
01369 */
01370 int mspace_trim(mspace msp, size_t pad);
01371 
01372 /*
01373   An alias for mallopt.
01374 */
01375 int mspace_mallopt(int, int);
01376 
01377 #endif /* MSPACES */
01378 
01379 #ifdef __cplusplus
01380 }  /* end of extern "C" */
01381 #endif /* __cplusplus */

01386   above this line, put into file malloc.h, edit to suit, and #include it
01387   on the next line, as well as in programs that use this malloc.
01388   ========================================================================
01389 */

01503 #ifndef WIN32
01504 #ifndef malloc_getpagesize
01505 #  ifdef _SC_PAGESIZE         /* some SVR4 systems omit an underscore */
01506 #    ifndef _SC_PAGE_SIZE
01507 #      define _SC_PAGE_SIZE _SC_PAGESIZE
01508 #    endif
01509 #  endif

01514        extern size_t getpagesize();

01518 #        define malloc_getpagesize getpagesize()

01529 #            else
01530 #              define malloc_getpagesize (NBPG * CLSIZE)
01531 #            endif
01532 #          else
01533 #            ifdef NBPC
01534 #              define malloc_getpagesize NBPC
01535 #            else
01536 #              ifdef PAGESIZE
01537 #                define malloc_getpagesize PAGESIZE
01538 #              else /* just guess */
01539 #                define malloc_getpagesize ((size_t)4096U)
01540 #              endif

01542 #          endif

01544 #      endif

01546 #  endif

01550 
01551 
01552 /* ------------------- size_t and alignment properties -------------------- */
01553 
01554 /* The byte and bit size of a size_t */
01555 #define SIZE_T_SIZE         (sizeof(size_t))
01556 #define SIZE_T_BITSIZE      (sizeof(size_t) << 3)
01557 
01558 /* Some constants coerced to size_t */
01559 /* Annoying but necessary to avoid errors on some platforms */
01560 #define SIZE_T_ZERO         ((size_t)0)
01561 #define SIZE_T_ONE          ((size_t)1)
01562 #define SIZE_T_TWO          ((size_t)2)
01563 #define SIZE_T_FOUR         ((size_t)4)
01564 #define TWO_SIZE_T_SIZES    (SIZE_T_SIZE<<1)
01565 #define THREE_SIZE_T_SIZES  (TWO_SIZE_T_SIZES+SIZE_T_SIZE)
01566 #define FOUR_SIZE_T_SIZES   (SIZE_T_SIZE<<2)
01567 #define SEVEN_SIZE_T_SIZES  (FOUR_SIZE_T_SIZES+TWO_SIZE_T_SIZES+SIZE_T_SIZE)
01568 #define HALF_MAX_SIZE_T     (MAX_SIZE_T / 2U)
01569 
01570 /* The bit mask value corresponding to MALLOC_ALIGNMENT */
01571 #define CHUNK_ALIGN_MASK    (MALLOC_ALIGNMENT - SIZE_T_ONE)
01572 
01573 /* True if address a has acceptable alignment */
01574 #define is_aligned(A)       (((size_t)((A)) & (CHUNK_ALIGN_MASK)) == 0)
01575 
01576 /* the number of bytes to offset an address to align it */
01577 #define align_offset(A)\
01578  ((((size_t)(A) & CHUNK_ALIGN_MASK) == 0)? 0 :\
01579   ((MALLOC_ALIGNMENT - ((size_t)(A) & CHUNK_ALIGN_MASK)) & CHUNK_ALIGN_MASK))
01580 
01581 /*
01582   malloc_params holds global properties, including those that can be
01583   dynamically set using mallopt. There is a single instance, mparams,
01584   initialized in init_mparams. Note that the non-zeroness of "magic"
01585   also serves as an initialization flag.
01586 */
01587 typedef unsigned int flag_t;
01588 struct malloc_params {
01589   volatile size_t magic;
01590   size_t page_size;
01591   size_t granularity;
01592   size_t mmap_threshold;
01593   size_t trim_threshold;
01594   flag_t default_mflags;
01595 };
01596 
01597 static struct malloc_params mparams;
01598 
01599 /* Ensure mparams initialized */
01600 #define ensure_initialization() (void)(mparams.magic != 0 || init_mparams())
01601 
01602 /* -------------------------- MMAP preliminaries ------------------------- */
01603 
01604 /*
01605    If HAVE_MORECORE or HAVE_MMAP are false, we just define calls and
01606    checks to fail so compiler optimizer can delete code rather than
01607    using so many "#if"s.
01608 */
01609 
01610 
01611 /* MORECORE and MMAP must return MFAIL on failure */
01612 #define MFAIL                ((void*)(MAX_SIZE_T))
01613 #define CMFAIL               ((char*)(MFAIL)) /* defined for convenience */
01614 
01615 #if HAVE_MMAP
01616 
01617 #ifndef MREMAP_MAYMOVE
01618 #define MREMAP_MAYMOVE 1
01619 #endif /* MREMAP_MAYMOVE */
01620 
01621 #ifdef ENABLE_LARGE_PAGES
01622 static int largepagesize = 0;
01623 #endif /* ENABLE_LARGE_PAGES */
01624 #ifndef WIN32
01625 #if !defined(MAP_ANONYMOUS) && defined(MAP_ANON)
01626 #define MAP_ANONYMOUS        MAP_ANON
01627 #endif /* MAP_ANON */
01628 #define MMAP_PROT            (PROT_READ|PROT_WRITE)
01629 #ifdef MAP_ANONYMOUS
01630 #define MMAP_FLAGS           (MAP_PRIVATE|MAP_ANONYMOUS)
01631 #else /* MAP_ANONYMOUS */
01632 #define MMAP_FLAGS           (MAP_PRIVATE)
01633 static int dev_zero_fd = -1; /* Cached file descriptor for /dev/zero. */
01634 #endif /* MAP_ANONYMOUS */
01635 
01636 #ifdef DEFAULT_GRANULARITY_ALIGNED
01637 static void* lastAlignedmmap; /* Used as a hint */
01638 #endif /* DEFAULT_GRANULARITY_ALIGNED */
01639 static FORCEINLINE void* posix_mmap(size_t size) {
01640   void* baseaddress = 0;
01641   void* ptr = 0;
01642   int flags = MMAP_FLAGS, fd = -1;
01643 #ifndef MAP_ANONYMOUS
01644   if (dev_zero_fd < 0)
01645     dev_zero_fd = open("/dev/zero", O_RDWR);
01646   fd = dev_zero_fd;
01647 #endif
01648 #ifdef ENABLE_LARGE_PAGES
01649 #ifdef MAP_LARGEPAGE
01650 #define MMAP_FLAGS_LARGEPAGE MAP_LARGEPAGE
01651 #elif defined(MAP_HUGETLB)
01652 #define MMAP_FLAGS_LARGEPAGE MAP_HUGETLB
01653 #else
01654 #error Cannot figure out how to enable large page support for this system!
01655 #endif
01656   if(largepagesize && size >= largepagesize && !(size & (largepagesize-1)))
01657     ptr = mmap(baseaddress, size, MMAP_PROT, flags|MMAP_FLAGS_LARGEPAGE, fd, 0);
01658 #endif
01659   if (!ptr) {
01660 #ifdef DEFAULT_GRANULARITY_ALIGNED
01661     void* originalbaseaddress;
01662     baseaddress = originalbaseaddress = lastAlignedmmap;
01663     for(;;) {
01664       if (baseaddress) flags|=MAP_FIXED;
01665       ptr = mmap(baseaddress, size, MMAP_PROT, flags, fd, 0);
01666       if (!ptr)
01667         baseaddress = (void*)((size_t)baseaddress + mparams.granularity);
01668       else if ((size_t)ptr & (mparams.granularity - SIZE_T_ONE)) {
01669         munmap(ptr, size);
01670         baseaddress = (void*)(((size_t)ptr + mparams.granularity) & ~(mparams.granularity - SIZE_T_ONE));
01671       }
01672       else break;
01673       if (baseaddress == originalbaseaddress) /* If this wraps then we are out of address space */
01674         return MFAIL;
01675     }
01676 #else
01677     ptr = mmap(baseaddress, size, MMAP_PROT, flags, fd, 0);
01678 #endif
01679   }
01680 #if DEBUG
01681     if (lastAlignedmmap && ptr!=lastAlignedmmap) printf("Non-contiguous mmap between %p and %p\n", ptr, lastAlignedmmap);
01682 #endif
01683 #ifdef DEFAULT_GRANULARITY_ALIGNED
01684   if (ptr) lastAlignedmmap = (void*)((size_t) ptr + mparams.granularity);
01685 #endif
01686   return ptr;
01687 }
01688 
01689 /* For direct MMAP, use MAP_GROWSDOWN (linux)|MAP_STACK (bsd) to minimize interference */
01690 static FORCEINLINE void* posix_direct_mmap(size_t size) {
01691   void* ptr = 0;
01692   int flags = MMAP_FLAGS, fd = -1;
01693 #ifndef MAP_ANONYMOUS
01694   if (dev_zero_fd < 0)
01695     dev_zero_fd = open("/dev/zero", O_RDWR);
01696   fd = dev_zero_fd;
01697 #endif
01698 #ifdef MAP_GROWSDOWN
01699   flags |= MAP_GROWSDOWN;
01700 #elif defined(MAP_STACK)
01701   flags |= MAP_STACK;
01702 #else
01703 #warning Cannot figure out how to request memory from the top of the address space!
01704 #endif
01705   ptr = mmap(0, size, MMAP_PROT, flags, fd, 0);
01706 #if DEBUG && 0
01707   printf("mmap returns %p size %u\n", ptr, size);
01708 #endif
01709   return (ptr != 0)? ptr: MFAIL;
01710 }
01711 
01712 #define MMAP_DEFAULT(s)                     posix_mmap(s)
01713 #define MUNMAP_DEFAULT(h, a, s)             munmap((a), (s))
01714 #define DIRECT_MMAP_DEFAULT(h, s, f)        posix_direct_mmap(s)
01715 #if HAVE_MREMAP
01716 #define MREMAP_DEFAULT(addr, osz, nsz, mv)  mremap((addr), (osz), (nsz), (mv))
01717 #define DIRECT_MREMAP_DEFAULT(h, addr, osz, nsz, mv, f) mremap((addr), (osz), (nsz), (mv))
01718 #endif /* HAVE_MREMAP */
01719 
01720 #else /* WIN32 */
01721 
01722 /* Win32 MMAP via VirtualAlloc */
01723 static size_t win32AllocationGranularity;
01724 #ifdef DEFAULT_GRANULARITY_ALIGNED
01725 static void* lastWin32mmap; /* Used as a hint */
01726 #endif /* DEFAULT_GRANULARITY_ALIGNED */
01727 static FORCEINLINE void* win32mmap(size_t size) {
01728   void* baseaddress = 0;
01729   void* ptr = 0;
01730 #ifdef ENABLE_LARGE_PAGES
01731   /* Note that large pages are *always* allocated on a large page boundary */
01732   if(largepagesize && size >= largepagesize && !(size & (largepagesize-1)) {
01733     ptr = VirtualAlloc(baseaddress, size, MEM_RESERVE|MEM_COMMIT|MEM_LARGE_PAGES, PAGE_READWRITE);
01734     if(!ptr) {
01735         if (ERROR_PRIVILEGE_NOT_HELD==GetLastError()) largepagesize=0;
01736     }
01737   }
01738 #endif
01739   if(!ptr) {
01740 #ifdef DEFAULT_GRANULARITY_ALIGNED
01741     /* We try to avoid overhead by speculatively reserving at aligned
01742     addresses until we succeed */
01743     void* originalbaseaddress;
01744     baseaddress = originalbaseaddress = lastWin32mmap;
01745     for(;;) {
01746       void* reserveaddr = VirtualAlloc(baseaddress, size, MEM_RESERVE, PAGE_READWRITE);
01747       if (!reserveaddr)
01748         baseaddress = (void*)((size_t)baseaddress + mparams.granularity);
01749       else if ((size_t)reserveaddr & (mparams.granularity - SIZE_T_ONE)) {
01750         VirtualFree(reserveaddr, 0, MEM_RELEASE);
01751         baseaddress = (void*)(((size_t)reserveaddr + mparams.granularity) & ~(mparams.granularity - SIZE_T_ONE));
01752       }
01753       else break;
01754       if (baseaddress == originalbaseaddress) /* If this wraps then we are out of address space */
01755         return MFAIL;
01756     }
01757 #endif
01758     if (!ptr) ptr = VirtualAlloc(baseaddress, size, baseaddress ? MEM_COMMIT : MEM_RESERVE|MEM_COMMIT, PAGE_READWRITE);
01759 #ifdef DEFAULT_GRANULARITY_ALIGNED
01760 #if DEBUG
01761     if (lastWin32mmap && ptr!=lastWin32mmap) printf("Non-contiguous VirtualAlloc between %p and %p\n", ptr, lastWin32mmap);
01762 #endif
01763     if (ptr) lastWin32mmap = (void*)((size_t) ptr + mparams.granularity);
01764 #endif
01765   }
01766 #if DEBUG && 0
01767 #ifdef ENABLE_LARGE_PAGES
01768   printf("VirtualAlloc returns %p size %u. LargePagesAvailable=%d\n", ptr, size, largepagesavailable);
01769 #else
01770   printf("VirtualAlloc returns %p size %u\n", ptr, size);
01771 #endif
01772 #endif
01773   return (ptr != 0)? ptr: MFAIL;
01774 }
01775 
01776 /* For direct MMAP, we have two allocation methods, one which is
01777 unresizeable and the other which is resizeable. The resizeable
01778 method is slower to allocate and free, but is much quicker to
01779 reallocate. Benchmarking shows that the crossover is at around
01780 512Kb-1Mb, so if you are reallocating blocks 1Mb or above then you
01781 ought to specify one of the M2_RESERVE_* flags which can specify
01782 a multiple of the allocation size or a fixed two power size.
01783 
01784 The mremap() Linux call is then effectively emulated by
01785 reserving the address space specified by M2_RESERVE_* and committing
01786 or decommitting memory as the block is resized. If the block
01787 exceeds its reservation size, the mremap() emulation fails and
01788 dlmalloc will allocate a new block, copy its contents and delete
01789 the old one.
01790 
01791 ************ The WIN32_DIRECT_USE_FILE_MAPPINGS option ************
01792 Reserving excessive address space is not an issue on 64 bit
01793 machines, but on 32 bit one can very quickly expend 2Gb. A
01794 solution is to use a win32 file mapping of the swap file as the
01795 reservation and then to map views of differing sizes which exactly
01796 is what mremap() does on Linux.
01797 
01798 Unfortunately the file mapping method is benchmarked at around
01799 40-45% slower than using VirtualAlloc to over-reserve. It is still
01800 50% faster for avrg. 2Mb block sizes than no mremap() at all, so
01801 we turn it on on 32 bit and disable it on 64 bit.
01802 */
01803 #ifndef WIN32_DIRECT_USE_FILE_MAPPINGS
01804 #if defined(_M_IA64) || defined(_M_X64) || defined(WIN64)
01805 #define WIN32_DIRECT_USE_FILE_MAPPINGS 0
01806 #else
01807 #define WIN32_DIRECT_USE_FILE_MAPPINGS 1
01808 #endif
01809 #endif
01810 
01811 static FORCEINLINE void* win32direct_mmap(void **handle, size_t size, unsigned flags) {
01812   void* ptr = 0;
01813   unsigned mremapvalue = (flags & M2_RESERVE_MASK)>>8;
01814 #if 0
01815   mremapvalue=4;
01816   flags|=M2_RESERVE_ISMULTIPLIER;
01817 #endif
01818 #if 0
01819   mremapvalue=22;/*4Mb*/
01820 #endif
01821   if (!mremapvalue) {
01822     ptr = VirtualAlloc(0, size, MEM_RESERVE|MEM_TOP_DOWN|MEM_COMMIT, PAGE_READWRITE);
01823   }
01824   else {
01825     size_t reservesize = (flags & M2_RESERVE_ISMULTIPLIER) ? size*mremapvalue : SIZE_T_ONE<<mremapvalue;
01826 #if WIN32_DIRECT_USE_FILE_MAPPINGS
01827     HANDLE fmh;
01828     if (reservesize < size)
01829       reservesize = size;
01830     fmh = CreateFileMapping(INVALID_HANDLE_VALUE, NULL, PAGE_READWRITE|SEC_RESERVE,
01831 #if defined(_M_IA64) || defined(_M_X64) || defined(WIN64)
01832                             (DWORD)(reservesize>>32),
01833 #else
01834                             0,
01835 #endif
01836                             (DWORD)(reservesize&((DWORD)-1)), NULL);
01837     if (!fmh)
01838       return MFAIL;
01839     *handle = (void*)fmh;
01840     ptr = MapViewOfFile(fmh, FILE_MAP_ALL_ACCESS, 0, 0, size);
01841     if (ptr)
01842       ptr = VirtualAlloc(ptr, size, MEM_COMMIT, PAGE_READWRITE);
01843     if (!ptr) {
01844       CloseHandle(fmh);
01845       return MFAIL;
01846     }
01847 #else
01848     void* ptr2;
01849     /* If on 32 bit, cap reservation to 1Gb */
01850     if (sizeof(size_t) == 4 && reservesize > 1*1024*1024*1024)
01851       reservesize = 1*1024*1024*1024;
01852     ptr = VirtualAlloc(0, reservesize, MEM_RESERVE|MEM_TOP_DOWN, PAGE_READWRITE);
01853     if (ptr) {
01854       ptr2 = VirtualAlloc(ptr, size, MEM_COMMIT, PAGE_READWRITE);
01855       if (ptr2)
01856         *handle = (void*)reservesize;
01857       else
01858         VirtualFree(ptr, 0, MEM_RELEASE);
01859     }
01860 #endif
01861   }
01862 #if DEBUG && 0
01863   printf("VirtualAlloc returns %p size %u\n", ptr, size);
01864 #endif
01865   return (ptr != 0)? ptr: MFAIL;
01866 }
01867 
01868 /* Implementation of mremap for direct MMAP */
01869 static FORCEINLINE void* win32direct_mremap(void **handle, void *ptr, size_t oldsize, size_t newsize, int flags, unsigned flags2) {
01870   void* newptr = 0;
01871   if (!*handle)
01872     return MFAIL; /* We only resize file mappings reserved with M2_RESERVE_* */
01873   if (newsize == oldsize)
01874     return ptr;
01875   {
01876 #if WIN32_DIRECT_USE_FILE_MAPPINGS
01877     HANDLE fmh = (HANDLE) *handle;
01878     /* It is VERY important to map a new view of a file mapping before
01879     unmapping the old view. Otherwise the NT kernel will start writing
01880     your file mapping in its entirety to the swap file which is otherwise
01881     avoidable. Hence fail if can't move. */
01882     if (!(flags & MREMAP_MAYMOVE))
01883       return MFAIL;
01884     newptr = MapViewOfFile(fmh, FILE_MAP_ALL_ACCESS, 0, 0, newsize);
01885     if (newptr && newsize > oldsize)
01886       newptr = VirtualAlloc(newptr, newsize, MEM_COMMIT, PAGE_READWRITE);
01887     if (!newptr)
01888       return MFAIL;
01889     UnmapViewOfFile(ptr);
01890 #else
01891     size_t reservesize = (size_t) *handle;
01892     if (newsize > reservesize)
01893       return MFAIL;
01894     if (newsize > oldsize) {
01895       if (VirtualAlloc((char*)ptr + oldsize, newsize - oldsize, MEM_COMMIT, PAGE_READWRITE) == 0)
01896         return MFAIL;
01897     }
01898     else {
01899       if (VirtualFree((char*)ptr + newsize, oldsize - newsize, MEM_DECOMMIT) == 0)
01900         return MFAIL;
01901     }
01902     newptr = ptr;
01903 #endif
01904   }
01905 #if DEBUG && 0
01906   printf("win32remap(%p, %u, %u, %d) returns %p!\n", ptr, oldsize, newsize, flags, newptr);
01907 #endif
01908   return newptr;
01909 }
01910 
01911 /* This function supports releasing coalesed segments */
01912 static FORCEINLINE int win32munmap(void *handle, void* ptr, size_t size) {
01913   if (!handle) {
01914     MEMORY_BASIC_INFORMATION minfo;
01915     char* cptr = (char*)ptr;
01916     while (size) {
01917       if (VirtualQuery(cptr, &minfo, sizeof(minfo)) == 0)
01918         return -1;
01919       if (minfo.BaseAddress != cptr || minfo.AllocationBase != cptr ||
01920           minfo.State != MEM_COMMIT || minfo.RegionSize > size)
01921         return -1;
01922       if (VirtualFree(cptr, 0, MEM_RELEASE) == 0)
01923         return -1;
01924       cptr += minfo.RegionSize;
01925       size -= minfo.RegionSize;
01926     }
01927   }
01928   else {
01929 #if WIN32_DIRECT_USE_FILE_MAPPINGS
01930     HANDLE fmh = (HANDLE) handle;
01931     /* As noted above in win32direct_mremap(), it is VERY important
01932     to destroy the file mapping object before unmapping views as so
01933     to avoid causing the system to write the file mapping to swap. */
01934     if (CloseHandle(fmh) == 0)
01935       return -1;
01936     if (UnmapViewOfFile(ptr) == 0)
01937       return -1;
01938 #else
01939     /* We know it's contiguous, so avoid the VirtualQuery() */
01940     if (VirtualFree(ptr, 0, MEM_RELEASE) == 0)
01941       return -1;
01942 #endif
01943   }
01944   return 0;
01945 }
01946 
01947 #define MMAP_DEFAULT(s)                        win32mmap(s)
01948 #define MUNMAP_DEFAULT(h, a, s)                win32munmap((h), (a), (s))
01949 #define DIRECT_MMAP_DEFAULT(h, s, f)           win32direct_mmap((h), (s), (f))
01950 #define DIRECT_MREMAP_DEFAULT(h, a, os, ns, f, f2) win32direct_mremap((h), (a), (os), (ns), (f), (f2))
01951 #endif /* WIN32 */
01952 
01953 #ifndef MREMAP_DEFAULT
01954 #define MREMAP_DEFAULT(addr, osz, nsz, mv)  MFAIL
01955 #endif /* MREMAP_DEFAULT */
01956 #ifndef DIRECT_MREMAP_DEFAULT
01957 #define DIRECT_MREMAP_DEFAULT(h, addr, osz, nsz, mv, f2) MFAIL
01958 #endif /* DIRECT_MREMAP_DEFAULT */
01959 
01960 #endif /* HAVE_MMAP */

01966 #if HAVE_MORECORE
01967     #ifdef MORECORE
01968         #define CALL_MORECORE(S)    MORECORE(S)
01969     #else  /* MORECORE */
01970         #define CALL_MORECORE(S)    MORECORE_DEFAULT(S)
01971     #endif /* MORECORE */
01972 #else  /* HAVE_MORECORE */
01973     #define CALL_MORECORE(S)        MFAIL
01974 #endif /* HAVE_MORECORE */
01975 
01979 #if HAVE_MMAP
01980     #define USE_MMAP_BIT                       (SIZE_T_ONE)

01982     #ifdef MUNMAP
